Daorong said:ğŸ”½Because sentient beings receive ignorance, there is craving. Because there is craving, they receive a body. Receiving a body is illness. Because of their illness, then my illness arises.

Newly practicing bodhisattvas are not yet able to dwell in birth and death for a long time, and give rise to illness for the sake of all, therefore it clarifies the great being's vast mind in the face of illness.

Pushing its prior limit, taking the initial arousal of the mind as the beginning, seeking its posterior limit, then it is extinguished together with sentient beings. Newly practicing ones hear this, their limited mind becomes vast.

The two phrases on the arising and extinguishing of illness, although the words are about illness, the meaning is in clarifying compassion, therefore it only discusses the near and far of the arising and extinguishing of illness.

This collection clarifies taking the essence as the basis, yet first speaking of great compassion, there are two gates to entering the Buddha Dharma:

The answer said:

If there were no liberation at all within the mental activities of all sentient beings, then we would know that liberation is what liberates them.

If there is no way to clarify that the sixty-two views are deviant, then it is also not sufficient to verify that emptiness is real.

A separate version says the sixty-two views, the liberation of the buddhas, and the mental activities of sentient beings. KumÄrajÄ«va said:
The two views are the root of existence and the extreme of wrongness.

These three aggregates of dharmas are where the emotions of the masses are stuck, definitely seeing them as different.
Those who grasp characteristics and give rise to delusions do so because of this. Those who seek the purport by going against delusion must also end up here.
The three natures lead to the same end, so they mutually penetrate each other.
Moreover, what you asked about having no attendants,

The attendants of the bodhisattvas are those who are arrogant, disobedient, and go against the Way. The demons delight in birth and death and thus abide within it.
If they are not transformed, they will forever be at odds with it. How can they be made to realize the principle of the school?
The non-Buddhists delight in various views, but the bodhisattvas are unmoved by various views.

Although the non-Buddhists seek to leave the world, they cling to their own path, so they are bound by wrong views.
The great being observes that birth and death are the same as nirvÄá¹‡a, so he is able not to abandon them;

Being unmoved and not abandoning, he is able to take them as attendants.

He also does not abandon various views.
